questions.text: On an endoscopic ultrasound the submucosal layer of esophagus appears as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) On an endoscopic USG 5 layers are seen in esophagus. These layers appear as alternate hyperechoic and hypoechoic. 1st layer- the superficial mucosa appears hyperechoic(white). 2nd layer is the muscularis mucosae appears hypoechoic. 3rd layer is submucosa appears hyperechoic. 4th layer is muscularis propria and appears hypoechoic. 5th layer is periesophageal tissue and appears hyperechoic.

questions.text: The motility disorder in esophagus seen more commonly in women, with simultaneous repetitive contractions of high amplitude , normal LES tone and degenerating branches of vagus is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The findings mentioned are classical manometeric findings of Diffuse esophageal spasm which according to the California classification is now called as Distal esophageal spasm. DES is associated with degenerating branches of vagus Nerve. In Achlasia cardia the LES tone is raised whereas in nutcracker (now called as hypercontractile as per Chicago classification) the peristaltic waves are of a very high amplitude but otherwise normal.

choices.text: Epiphrenic diverticula are Pulsion diverticula and have a predilection to involve the region around 5 cm distal to the carina
Most traction diverticula arise within 4-5 cm proximal or distal to the carina
Epiphrenic diverticula can be premalignant for squamous cell ca of esophagus
Dohlman’s procedure is the endoscopic management of Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text: Regarding esophageal diverticula, the false statement is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Epiphrenic diverticula , most commonly arise in the distal esophagus within 10 cm of GE junction

choices.text: Developmental anomaly of arteries causing dysphagia
Vascular slings need treatment only in case they are symptomatic.
Aberrant Right SCA forms a complete vascular ring
Aberrant Right SCA forms Posterior compression of esophagus

questions.text: The false statement about dysphagia Lusoria is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Aberrant SCA forms an incomplete ring around esophagus. Pulmonary slings need treatment even if asymptomatic

choices.text: Risk for malignancy is more for adenoca as compared to squamous cell ca.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Achlasia cardia is not true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Achlasia cardia more commonly is associated with squammous cell ca as compared to adenoca. May lead to adenoca below the air fluid level in middle esophagus.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient complains of haematemesis after retching and vomiting following a night of binge drinking. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a mucosal tear just below the gastroesophageal junction which is not actively bleeding. Which of the following is MOST appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This is a clinical scenario suggestive of Mallory Wiess tear which is usually a self limiting condition. Since there is no active bleeding on endoscopy patient just needs a supportive treatment and observation.

questions.text: A 55-years old male had retrosternal discomfort unrelated to physical exertion. Pain gets worse after lying down there is partial relief with antacids. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is Correct as the the symptoms given in the question point towards a diagnosis of GERD and reflux which is present with hiatal hernia. Option A is not the answer as Ischemic heart disease is associated with pain radiating along the arm along with severe chest pain.Pain is not related to change in position. Option B is not the answer as esophageal carcinoma also presents with Dysphagia and has no relation with antacids . Option C is no the answer as Achalasia cardia presents with dysphagia and not reflux and the symptoms of achalasia do not resolve with antacids.

choices.text: Most common type is sliding hiatal hernia
In Sliding hiatal hernia GE junction moves proximally
Cameron ulcer is associated with sliding hiatal hernia

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Hiatal Hernia is false ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is wrong as Cameron's ulcers are linear ulcers on stomach due to pressure of diaphragm and this is a feature of Rolling Hiatal Hernia Option A: Sliding hiatal hernia is the most common type of hiatal hernia. Option B: In sliding hiatal hernia the GE Junction is moved proximally so it is associated with GERD, GERD is the most common presentation of Sliding Hiatal Hernia. Option D: Toupet is 180 degree posterior wrap . Watson is 90 degree anterior wrap Dor is 180 degree anterior fundoplication Belsey mark is 270 degree anterior fundoplication Nissens is 360 degree fundoplication

choices.text: Lateral X-rays on barium swallow are often diagnostic
Outpouching of the anterior pharyngeal wall just above the cricopharyngeus muscle

questions.text: All of the following statements about Zenker’s diverticulum are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is false as zenker's diverticulum starts as a midline swelling between fibers of thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus posteriorly but comes to lie in a lateral position mostly on left side as the diverticulum progresses . Option A: Zenker's Diverticulum is an acquired diverticulum as it arises when the intraluminal pressure in the trachea increases due to neuromuscular discoordination between fibers of thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus Option B: Lateral X-ray on barium swallow is the investigation of choice for zenker's diverticulum. Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a false diverticulum as it has only the mucosa in its wall it does not have muscle layer surrounding it.

questions.text: Dohlman’s procedure is used in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dohlman’s Procedure is used for Zenker’s Diverticulum Treatment is directed toward correcting the underlying sphincter dysfunction and managing the diverticulum. Endoscopic diverticulotomy requires division of the cricopharyngeus and the common wall between the esophagus and diverticulum, a technique popularized by Dohlman.

choices.text: Most common cause of esophageal perforation is Boerhaave's Syndrome
Prompt repair of esophageal perforation is done
Diagnostic test for esophageal perforation is X-ray chest
Subcutaneous emphysema is not seen in esophageal perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about esophageal perforation is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The correct answer to this question is B. After the diagnosis of esophageal perforation has been made we need to go for emergent repair of the perforation. Instrumental perforation of the esophagus is by far the most common reason for esophageal perforation. Shortly after completion of endoscopy, symptoms as described above will develop. There may be emphysema in the lower neck (virtually diagnostic in this setting). Contrast studies and prompt repair are imperative. Iatrogenic esophageal perforation: At upper 1/3rd of esophagus IOC for esophageal perforation: CECT

questions.text: Most common presenting feature of esophageal carcinoma is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common presenting feature of esophageal carcinoma is dysphagia Dysphagia is more of solid than liquid in esophageal Carcinoma while in Achalasia cardia is more of liquid than solid Option B. Weight loss also occurs in esophageal carcinoma patients but it is a late feature. Option C. Persistent cough can occur because of Ca esophagus if it leads to tracheoesophageal fistula. Patients will develop cyanosis and dyspnea Option D. Hoarseness of voice occurs in Ca esophagus if there is involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Best investigation to look for T and N stage in esophageal carcinoma patients is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B. Best investigation to look for the T and N stage of the tumour is EUS (Endoscopic Ultrasound) Option A . Endoscopic biopsy is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of esophageal Ca Option C. PET-CT is the best investigation for overall staging in CA esophagus. Option D. There is no specific indication to perform an MRI in patients of Esophageal Ca. Mucosa : White (hypereochoic) Muscularis mucosa : Black Submucosa : White Muscularis Propria : Black

questions.text: Margin of resection to be taken while operating in a patient of Ca Esophagus ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A. 0.1 cm is the margin to be taken while operating in a breast lesion while performing Breast conservative surgery Option B. 2 cm is the margin taken while performing wide local excision in a soft tissue Option C. 5 cm is the margin which is taken while operating in a patient of Ca Stomach Option D. 10 cm proximal margin and 5 cm distal margin kept in mind while operating on esophageal carcinoma.

questions.text: Anastomotic leak is the most common cause of death in which esophageal cancer surgery ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A. Ivor Lewis surgery is a type of esophagectomy in which we put two incisions, one in abdomen and one in right thoracic region. In this esophageal anastomosis is performed in the thorax and if this leaks there is a high chance of mortality . So anastomotic leak is the most common complication of ivor lewis surgery as well as most common cause of death. Option B. Orringer transhiatal esophagectomy is performed by putting two incisions. One in abdomen and another in the left cervical region. In this the esophageal anastomosis is created in the cervical region. Anastomotic leak is the most common complication of this procedure but this is a self limiting condition and does not leads to death of the patient. Option C. Mckeown esophagectomy is performed by putting three incisions one in abdomen, another in thorax and third in left cervical region. Most common cause mortality in this procedure is respiratory compromise

questions.text: Treatment of choice for malignant tracheoesophageal fistula is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Treatment of choice for malignant tracheoesophageal fistula is coated SEMS (Self Expandable Metallic Stents) . They look like as follows :

questions.text: Which of the following conduit is not used for esophageal replacement after esophagectomy ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Duodenum is not used for esophageal replacement after esophagectomy . Option A. Stomach is the preferred conduit for esophageal replacement after esophagectomy. It is based on right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery. If the esophagectomy is being performed for corrosive acid poisoning then we can not use stomach as a conduit we have to use colon as a conduit. Option B. Colon is a preferred conduit to be used after esophagectomy done for corrosive acid poisoning. Left colon is based on left colic artery. Option D. Jejunum can be used as an esophageal conduit for short segment diseases.

choices.text: It is the most common benign tumour of esophagus
On barium it shows as a well demarcated lesion.
FNAC is done to diagnose the condition.
Enucleation is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about leiomyoma of esophagus is false ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) we do not do FNAC in leiomyoma of esophagus as after doing FNAC it is difficult to do enucleation of the lesion. Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign lesion of the esophagus. Barium studies show it as a well demarcated lesion. Endoscopic USG can help to make the diagnosis but FNAC should not be done. Treatment is enucleation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Allgrove syndrome ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Allgrove syndrome is also referred to as a triple A syndrome. The constituents of allgrove syndrome are A: Alacrimia A: Achalasia A: Adrenal Insufficiency

choices.text: Primary achalasia is because of absence of the ganglion cells
Secondary achalasia is because of chagas disease
Pseudo achalasia is same as secondary achalasia
In achalasia cardia patients risk of malignancy increases 20 to 25 times

questions.text: Which of the following statement about achalasia cardia is false ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) pseudoachalasia is not the same as secondary achalasia. Pseudoachalasia is a condition where we have achalasia like features but the ganglion cells are normal. It occurs in elderly patients and those who have carcinoma of esophagus. Option A. Primary achalasia is a condition where we have loss of ganglion cells in the lower part of esophagus. Option B. Secondary achalasia develops in chagas disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi which leads to destruction of the ganglion cells. Option D. Achalasia cardia is a risk factor for development of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus and the risk of carcinoma increases by 20 to 25 times.

questions.text: POEM is a treatment option for ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) POEM : Per Oral Endoscopic Myotomy is a treatment option for achalasia cardia POEM represents a new paradigm for achalasia treatment. It combines the minimally invasive benefit of endoscopy with the durability of a surgical myotomy. First performed in 2008, POEM uses a flexible upper endoscope to create a small incision into the mucosa of the esophagus. The endoscope is then tunneled into the esophageal wall and an endoscopic myotomy is performed (analogous to one performed during a traditional Heller myotomy). Once complete, the esophageal mucosal incision is closed using clips. Option A. GERD is managed by medical drugs which prevent the acid reflux and in later stage we need to do a fundoplication for GERD. Option C. Leiomyoma of esophagus is managed by enucleation Option D. Barrett's esophagus can be managed by ablation of the mucosa followed by fundoplication.

choices.text: Esophageal diverticulum can be a true or a false diverticula
Zenker's diverticulum arises posteriorly in midline

questions.text: Which of the following statements about esophageal diverticulum is false ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Epiphrenic diverticulum is also a false diverticulum or a pulsion diverticulum and not a true diverticulum. Option A and C Esophageal diverticulum can be a true or a false diverticulum, true diverticulum are the ones which have all the three layers of the wall of the intestine and peribronchial diverticulum is a type of a true diverticulum .It occurs after the inflammation of the lymph nodes surrounding the middle part of the esophagus subsides they pull the esophagus along with it and lead to traction diverticulum. Zenker's and Epiphrenic diverticulum are the types of pulsion diverticulum and so they are false diverticulum as they contain only the mucosa.

questions.text: Most common source of bleed after mallory weiss syndrome is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In mallory weiss tear the most common source of bleed is a left gastric artery. The source of bleed in mallory weiss tear is arterial so sengstaken blakemore tube is not effective for mallory weiss tear.

choices.text: In the middle third of the esophagus

questions.text: A foreign body usually gets arrested in which part of esophagus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The first constriction where the esophagus commences is at the cricopharyngeal sphincter this is the narrowest portion of the esophagus and is the most common site of foreign body.

choices.text: Occurs at lower part of esophagus

questions.text: False about Schatzki Ring is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Schatzki's rings are only the mucosal rings and they do not have a muscle coat in them . Diagnosis : Barium Swallow : 'B' ring appearance A ring : Proximal limit of vestibule B ring : Schatzki's ring at squamocolumnar junction C : Distal limit of hiatal hernia MX : Asymptomatic: Observation Symptomatic: Balloon dilatation

questions.text: Most common anomaly associated with tracheoesophageal fistula is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most common anomaly associated with tracheoesophageal fistula is Cardiac anomalies and in cardiac anomalies it is Ventricular septal defect Options B, C and D Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL group of anomalies . V: Vertebral A: Anal atresia C: Cardiovascular (PDA and VSD) TE: Tracheoesophageal fistula R: Renal (unilateral renal agenesis) L: Limb anomalies (Radial hypoplasia)

questions.text: Most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Types of Tracheoesophageal fistula Type A: Esophageal atresia with no tracheoesophageal fistula Type B: Proximal tracheoesophageal fistula with atretic distal end. Type C: Proximal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula. ( 85 %) : Most Common Type D: Atresia with both proximal and distal tracheoesophageal fistula . Type E: Tracheoesophageal fistula (H type )

choices.text: Barium swallow with water soluble contrast

questions.text: Investigation of choice for Diagnosing H-type tracheoesophageal fistula is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) For diagnosing H-type tracheoesophageal fistula ,Tracheo-esophagoscopy needs to be performed.

choices.text: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is more common on left side
Bag and mass respiration is contraindicated

questions.text: A new born child has been referred to the hospital from the primary health centre with respiratory distress. X-ray chest of the child shoes the following finding. Which of the following statement is true ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is also referred to as bochdalek's hernia. CDH is more common on left side (80 % of cases) Option B. CDH presents with the triad of respiratory distress + Scaphoid abdomen and Dextrocardia Option C. Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in CDH as bag and mask ventilation will lead to the inflation of the intestines in the lung which will push the opposite lung and further exaggerate the respiratory distress.

choices.text: Due to aberrant subclavian artery causing pressure on esophagus

questions.text: All are true about dysphagia lusoria except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dysphagia lusoria (or Bayford-Autenrieth dysphagia) is an congenital condition characterized by difficulty in swallowing caused by an aberrant right subclavian artery or vascular ring or right aortic arch.

questions.text: Mackler’s triad includes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B & C) Mackler's triad includes chest pain, vomiting, and subcutaneous emphysema, and while it is a classical presentation, it is only present in 14% of people. Pain can occasionally radiate to the left shoulder, causing physicians to confuse an esophageal perforation with a myocardial infarction. It may also be audibly recognized as Hamman's sign.

questions.text: Patient after a routine upper GI endoscopy presents with following finding. What is the probable diagnosis of the patient ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Patient is presenting with subcutaneous emphysema which is a feature of esophageal rupture. Upper GI endoscopy can lead to esophageal rupture just distal to the cricopharynx and thus the most probable diagnosis is esophageal rupture.

questions.text: Feline esophagus is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In eosinophilic esophagitis, a type of white blood cell (eosinophil) builds up in the lining of esophagus. This buildup, which is a reaction to foods, allergens or acid reflux, can inflame or injure the esophageal tissue. Damaged esophageal tissue can lead to difficulty swallowing or cause food to get stuck when you swallow. Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic immune system disease. Endoscopically, ridges, furrows, or rings may be seen in the esophageal wall. Sometimes, multiple rings may occur in the esophagus, leading to the term "corrugated esophagus" or "feline esophagus" due to similarity of the rings to the cat esophagus. Presence of white exudates in esophagus is also suggestive of the diagnosis. Radiologically, the term "ringed esophagus" has been used for the appearance of eosinophilic esophagitis on barium swallow studies to contrast with the appearance of transient transverse folds sometimes seen with esophageal reflux (termed "feline esophagus”) Option B . In hiatal hernia we see Cameron's ulcer in the fundus . Options C and D . These are not associated with feline esophagus.

questions.text: Laryngo Pharyngo esophageal reflux is monitored by ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR), is the retrograde flow of gastric contents into the larynx, oropharynx and/or the nasopharynx.LPR causes respiratory symptoms such as cough and wheezing and is often associated with head and neck complaints such as dysphonia, globus pharyngeus, and dysphagia. LPR may play a role in other diseases, such as sinusitis, otitis media, and rhinitis,and can be a comorbidity of asthma. Laryngopharyngeal reflux disease (LPRD) cases are common in clinical practice and usually neglected for want of a definitive diagnosis. Diagnosis requires a documented evidence of fall in pH levels in the laryngopharynx with dual-probe 24-hour ambulatory pH-metry.

questions.text: Serpiginous ulcers in lower esophagus on esophagoscopy are seen in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CMV classically causes serpiginous ulcers in the distal esophagus that may coalesce to form giant ulcers. Brushings alone are insufficient for diagnosis, and biopsies must be performed. Biopsies reveal intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions with enlarged nuclei in large fibroblasts and endothelial cells. Given her notable swallowing symptoms, IV ganciclovir is the treatment of choice. Valganciclovir is an effective oral preparation. Foscarnet is useful in treating ganciclovir-resistant CMV. Option B. Candida esophagitis has the appearance of yellow nodular plaques with surrounding erythema. Treatment usually requires fluconazole therapy. Option D. HIV can cause esophagitis that can be quite resistant to therapy. On EGD these ulcers appear deep and linear. Treatment with thalidomide or oral glucocorticoids is employed, and highly active antiretroviral therapy should be considered.

questions.text: Small Punched out lesions on endoscopy in lower esophagus in the immunocompromised patients is seen in ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Herpes simplex virus manifests as vesicles and punched-out lesions in the esophagus, with the characteristic finding on biopsy of ballooning degeneration with ground-glass changes in the nuclei. It can be treated with acyclovir or foscarnet in resistant cases. Option A. CMV classically causes serpiginous ulcers in the distal esophagus that may coalesce to form giant ulcers. Brushings alone are insufficient for diagnosis, and biopsies must be performed. Biopsies reveal intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions with enlarged nuclei in large fibroblasts and endothelial cells. IV ganciclovir is the treatment of choice. Valganciclovir is an effective oral preparation. Foscarnet is useful in treating ganciclovir-resistant CMV. Option B. Candida esophagitis has the appearance of yellow nodular plaques with surrounding erythema. Treatment usually requires fluconazole therapy.

questions.text: Dysphagia in esophagus means invasion of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dysphagia in esophagus is with transmural invasion.

questions.text: Normal LES pressure is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normal LES pressure is 6-26mm Hg For the spincter to be mechanicaly defective one or more of the following should be present: 1. LES pressure less than 6mm Hg. 2. Average intraabdominal length less than 1 cm. 3. Average total length of LES less than 2cm. Most common cause of defective LOWER ESOPHAGEAL SPHINCTER is inadequate intraabdominal length

choices.text: Most patients managed by conservative management

questions.text: Which of the following is true about boerhaave syndrome ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Boerhaave syndrome may result in peritonitis. Option B. It is caused by forceful vomiting against closed glottis, not open glottis. Option C. It usually leads to rupture in lower part of esophagus. Option D. It is a type of esophageal perforation and has led to mediastinitis. It is not kept or managed conservatively.

questions.text: In esophageal Ca prognosis is best determined by ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In esophageal carcinoma the prognosis of the disease is best determined by T stage of the disease.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient with progressive dysphagia. Barium swallow was done, what is the name of the sign?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In this barium study you have been shown a apple core appearance. It is a sign of esophageal Ca . Options A and C. Bird’s beak sign and pencil tip sign point towards achalasia

questions.text: Commonest site of esophageal Ca . ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Most common site of esophaeal Ca is western countries is Lower 1/3rd of esophagus. Most common site of esophageal Ca overall is middle 1/3rd of esophagus. Most common Ca in lower 1/3rd is adeno Ca Most common Ca in middle 1/3rd id squamous cell Ca.

questions.text: Classification system used for esophageal motility disorders ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Latest Chicago classification is based on high resolution manometry .

questions.text: Corkscrew esophagus is seen in which of the following condition ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is a condition characterized by uncoordinated contractions of the esophagus, which may cause difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) or regurgitation. In some cases, it may cause symptoms such as chest pain, similar to heart disease. The cause of DES remains unknown. Certain abnormalities on x-ray imaging are commonly observed in DES, such as a "corkscrew" or "rosary bead esophagus", although these findings are not unique to this condition. Specialized testing called manometry can be performed to evaluate the motor function of the esophagus, which can help identify abnormal patterns of muscle contraction within the esophagus that are suggestive of DES. The treatment of DES consists primarily of medications, such as acid suppressing agents (like proton pump inhibitors), calcium channel blockers, hyoscine butylbromide, or nitrates. Option A. In Ca esophagus we see apple core appearance Option C. In achalasia we see pencil tip appearance and bird’s beak appearance

questions.text: Most common motility disorder leading to dysphagia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Achalasia is characterized by difficulty in swallowing, regurgitation, and sometimes chest pain. Diagnosis is reached with esophageal manometry and barium swallow radiographic studies. Various treatments are available, although none cures the condition. Certain medications or Botox may be used in some cases, but more permanent relief is brought by esophageal dilatation and surgical cleaving of the muscle (Heller myotomy). The most common form is primary achalasia, which has no known underlying cause. It is due to the failure of distal esophageal inhibitory neurons. However, a small proportion occurs secondary to other conditions, such as esophageal cancer, Chagas disease (an infectious disease common in South America) or Triple-A syndrome. Achalasia affects about one person in 100,000 per year. There is no gender predominance for the occurrence of disease.

questions.text: Which of the following surgery is shown in the following figure ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Watson is 90 degree anterior wrap Dor is 180 degree anterior fundoplication Belsey mark is 270 degree anterior fundoplication Nissons is 360 degree fundoplication

questions.text: Which of the following drugs exacerbate reflux esophagitis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: In surgical procedure NOTES entry point is through ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery (NOTES) is an experimental surgical technique whereby "scarless" abdominal operations can be performed with an endoscope passed through a natural orifice (mouth, urethra, anus, etc.) then through an internal incision in the stomach, vagina, bladder or colon, thus avoiding any external incisions or scars. Considering N.O.T.E.S employs a non-abdominal approach, the potential advantages include reduced post operative pain along with the reduced risk of surgical wound related complications like wound infections and incisional hernia.

questions.text: A patient presented with regurgitation of food with foul smelling breath and intermittent dysphagia to solid foods. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: (c) Zenker’s diverticulum Zenker’s diverticulum presents as intermittent dysphagia with regurgitation and foul breath initially which becomes progressive later on. Achalasia cardia on the other hand presents as dysphagia to liquids initially which later on progress to involve solids as well. Commonest presentation of trachea-esophageal fistula is violent cough during meals causing feeding difficulty.

choices.text: Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube
Suction of tube with sodium bicarbonate

questions.text: A tracheostomized patient, with portex tracheostomy tube, in the ward, developed sudden complete blockage of the tube. What will be the best next step for the management?
questions.solution: (a) Immediate removal of the tracheostomy tube Portex tube is cuffed and is devoid of an inner tube. Complete obstruction of the tube hence amounts to total airway obstruction and can lead to serious consequences. Hence immediate removal of the tube is required to find out the cause of obstruction.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male has typical symptoms of GERD refractory to medical management and is referred to your clinic to discuss surgical options. He has previously had a distal pancreatectomy/splenectomy from a gunshot wound and three subsequent laparotomies for adhesive bowel obstruction. What surgical option allows for satisfactory control of reflux while avoiding the abdomen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The Belsey Mark-IV operation recreates the LES while reducing an intrathoracic stomach and closing a hiatal defect. This operation is approached via a left thoracotomy, allowing the surgeon to avoid a hostile abdomen This approach can also be useful in the dissection of large and giant chronic paraesophageal hernias. The Belsey Mark-IV provides a 240-degree partial wrap, imbricating cardia against the distal esophagus. Each of the other operations requires an abdominal approach. The Toupet is a 270-degree, posterior partial wrap, while the Dor is a 180-degree anterior partial wrap. The Hill operation focuses on the creation of a gastroesophageal flap valve in an attempt to recreate normal anatomy.

choices.text: Cystic transformation or central necrosis is often associated with these lesions
Patients often have hematemesis or chronic anemia because of ulceration
Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) will show a hypoechoic mass in the submucosa.
Endoscopic biopsy should be performed to rule out malignancy

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is evaluated for dysphagia and chest pain. A barium oesophagogram shows a 3-cm smooth filling defect in the distal end of the esophagus. Which of the following is true of his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Benign tumors of the esophagus are rare and represent less than 1% of esophageal neoplasms. Leiomyomas account for 60% of these lesions and are often found in the distal two-thirds of the esophagus. Most of these tumors are asymptomatic. Pain and dysphagia are the most common complaints. They have a characteristic smooth filling defect on contrast-enhanced study and are described as a hypoechoic mass within the submucosa or muscularis propria on EUS. Recently, they have been classified as a gastrointestinal stromal tumor. Most of these tumors occur from mutations of the c-KIT oncogene. Leiomyomas are removed by enucleation, and biopsy should be avoided because of the increased risk for perforation.

choices.text: It can be caused by infection with Trypanosoma cruzi
It is the result of fibrous replacement of the esophageal smooth muscle.
It is also known as “vigorous” achalasia

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of chest pain and dysphagia. Manometric studies show simultaneous multipeaked contractions of 140 mmHg, lasting 4 to 5 s, and normal LES relaxation. Which of the following is true of her disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) DES(diffuse oesophageal spam) is a poorly understood motility disorder of the esophagus. Chest pain and dysphagia are often present. The diagnosis is made by esophagography demonstrating a classic picture of a corkscrew esophagus. Manometry will show simultaneous multipeaked contractions similar to those seen in achalasia; however, the LES will have normal receptive relaxation. A variant of achalasia in which amplitude pressure is normal or elevated is also known as vigorous achalasia. Pharmacotherapy (nitrates, calcium channel blockers, and phosphodiesterase inhibitors) aimed at smooth muscle relaxation is the first-line treatment of DES. Bougie or pneumatic dilations are used with variable results for severe dysphagia with documented LES hypertension. Surgery, which involves a long esophagomyotomy from the level of the aortic arch to the LES, is reserved for patients who fail pharmacologic and endoscopic therapies.

choices.text: Oral dilation is the treatment of choice.
It is the result of hypertrophy of the circular muscle layer.
There is squamous mucosa above and below the narrowing.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has GERD and episodic dysphagia. An upper gastrointestinal contrast-enhanced study shows a type I hiatal hernia and thin band-like narrowing of the distal end of the esophagus. Which of the following is true of his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Schatzki rings are concentric constrictions of the distal end of the esophagus occurring at the squamocolumnar junction; as a result, there is esophageal mucosa above and gastric mucosa below. The rings consist of muscularis mucosa, connective tissue, and submucosal fibrosis. Treatment involves oral dilation, which can provide relief for up to 18 months. Excision of the rings should be avoided because of the esophageal strictures that result from resection are much more difficult to manage.

choices.text: Primary peristalsis is triggered voluntarily after swallowing
Secondary peristalsis is involuntary and triggered by esophageal distension or irritation
Tertiary peristalsis involves uncoordinated waves that are nonprogressive and nonperistaltic

questions.text: True amongst the following statement are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Esophageal peristalsis is separated into primary, secondary, and tertiary peristalsis as delineated on manometry. Primary peristalsis is triggered voluntarily after swallowing but becomes involuntary after initiation. Waves travel the entire length of the esophagus and work to propel the food bolus toward the stomach. Secondary peristalsis is involuntary and triggered by esophageal distension or irritation. They are thought to have defensive purposes working to propel reflux contents back toward the stomach. Tertiary peristalsis involves uncoordinated waves that are nonprogressive and nonperistaltic, representing smooth muscle contractions and related to motility disorders and spasm.

choices.text: The pH probe is placed in the upper oesophagus
The oesophageal pH of < 4 is considered the cut – off
In a normal individual, a pH <4 is seen in less than 4 % of the 24 hour period

questions.text: True about oesophageal pH manometry are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Prolonged measurement of pH is now accepted as the most accurate method for the diagnosis of gastro-oesophageal reflux. It is particularly useful in patients with atypical reflux symptoms, those without endoscopic oesophagitis and when patients respond poorly to intensive medical therapy. A small pH probe is passed into the distal oesophagus and positioned 5 cm above the upper margin of the LOS, as defined by manometry. The probe is connected to a miniature digital recorder that is worn on a belt and allows most normal activities. Patients mark symptomatic events such as heartburn. A 24-hour recording period is usual, and the pH record is analysed by an automated computer program. An oesophageal pH <4 at the level of the pH electrode is conventionally considered the cut-off value and, in most oesophageal laboratories, the total time when pH is <4 in a 24-hour period does not exceed 4% in a healthy adult. Patterns of reflux and the correlation between symptoms and oesophageal pH <4 can be calculated. Most laboratories use a scoring system (Johnson–DeMeester) to create a numerical value, above which reflux is considered pathological.

choices.text: Ivor Lewis esophagectomy involves an upper midline laparotomy and a left thoracotomy.
Transthoracic esophagectomy (TTE) is associated with a lower total hospital length of stay when compared to a transhiatal esophagectomy (THE).
There is no difference in mortality between the use of TTE or THE in the surgical treatment of esophageal cancer.
TTE is associated with fewer complications when compared with THE.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding surgical intervention for esophageal cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The three standard approaches for esophageal carcinoma include TTE, THE, and a combination of the two using a three-incision esophagectomy. TTH was initially described as a two-stage procedure by Dr. Ivor Lewis in which he performed mobilization of the stomach using an upper midline laparotomy incision followed by resection of the esophagus using a right thoracotomy incision several days later A large multicenter prospective study comparing THE and TTE failed to demonstrate any difference in overall mortality and morbidity between the two approaches However, THE has been shown in several studies to be associated with a lower total hospital length of stay

choices.text: The chief pathologic finding is spontaneous perforation of the esophagus.
It typically occurs on the right side.
It is usually associated with air in the mediastinum
Endoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which one of the following is true about Mallory-Weiss syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The mechanism of a Mallory-Weiss tear is similar to that of an esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome), but differs in that the injury is not full thickness (A). It is the result of forceful vomiting or coughing, such as after an alcohol drinking binge. The classic description is retching followed by vomiting of blood. The presence of a hiatal hernia is a predisposing factor and is found in a majority of patients. This situation exposes the LES to high pressures, which results in a partial-thickness mucosal tear and bleeding most commonly 3 to 5 cm above the gastroesophageal junction on the left side (B). Boerhaave syndrome results in a full-thickness tear causing esophageal perforation (A). These patients often present in sepsis with air in the mediastinum and a pleural effusion. Severe sepsis in the setting of esophageal perforation mandates surgical intervention (C). Most bleeding from Mallory-Weiss tears stops spontaneously with nonsurgical management

choices.text: It is best diagnosed with esophagoscopy.
It is unlikely to cause aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Zenker diverticulum?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A Zenker diverticulum is a false, esophageal diverticulum that does not contain all layers of the esophagus; it is also a type of pulsion diverticulum (A). A pulsion diverticulum forms at a point of weakness and is due to alterations in luminal pressure. Conversely, a traction diverticulum is from external pulling on the esophageal wall, such as from inflamed lymph nodes with tuberculosis. Zenker diverticulum is the most common type of esophageal diverticulum. It usually presents in older patients (>60 years). It characteristically arises at a point of weakness, most commonly at the Killian triangle, which is formed by the inferior fibers of the inferior constrictor muscle and the superior border of the cricopharyngeus muscle. Patients typically present with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, episodes of aspiration, and salivation (C). With the characteristic history, the first diagnostic study is a barium swallow. In the absence of other pathology (such as an irregular mucosa), endoscopy is not needed (B). Treatment is surgical

questions.text: Dysphagia lusoria is most likely associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dysphagia lusoria (dysphagia by a freak of nature) refers to difficulty in swallowing due to compression of the esophagus by an aberrant right subclavian artery. The aberrant right subclavian artery arises distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery in the descending thoracic aorta, traverses the mediastinum posterior to the esophagus and trachea, and then follows the course of the normal artery into the right upper extremity. It is usually asymptomatic. The most common associated symptom is dysphagia associated with compression of the esophagus between the trachea and the artery.

choices.text: Dysphagia associated with pre – cricoid web
Webs occur in upper and middle oesophagus
Webs are easily ruptured at endoscopy

questions.text: True about Plummer Vinson syndrome are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dysphagia is associated with post – cricoid web and not pre – cricoid web. also known as Paterson brown Kelly syndrome or sideropenic dysphagia. Dysphagia is said to occur because of the presence of a postcricoid web that is associated with iron deficiency anaemia, glossitis and koilonychia. The classic syndrome is rarely complete. Webs certainly occur in the upper and middle oesophagus, usually without any kind of associated syndrome. Even symptomatic webs that cause a degree of obstruction may be inadvertently ruptured at endoscopy. Few require formal endoscopic dilatation.

questions.text: Most common type of hiatus hernia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Types of hiatus hernia – classification • Type I hiatus hernia – It is the cephalad displacement of the gastrooesophageal junction through the hiatus into the mediastinum. It is usually small, asymptomatic and reducible. It is commonest type • Type II hiatus hernia – It is superior migration of the fundus of the stomach along side the GE junction and oesophagus into the mediastinum with GE junction in normal intraabdominal location. It is rolling hernia • Type III hiatus hernia – It is combination of type I and type II • Type IV hiatus hernia – It is the hernia containing other abdominal viscera as content like transverse colon and omentum

choices.text: The disorders of this group are classified under the Chicago classification
T. cruzi infection can cause similar symptoms
Peroral endoscopic myotomy is an available treatment modality

questions.text: 20-year-old female presents with dysphagia to liquids and regurgitation. A barium swallow was done. What is false regarding the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Achalasia is due to loss of the ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus, the cause of which is unknown. In South America, chronic infection with the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas’ disease, which has marked clinical similarities to achalasia. Oesophageal motility disorders are currently best classified by incorporation of the Chicago classification developed for use with high-resolution manometry. The classic physiological abnormalities are a non-relaxing LOS and absent peristalsis in the body of the oesophagus. The Chicago classification identifies three variants. Although most patients have almost no recognisable contractions (type I), some patients continue to exhibit pressurisation throughout the oesophagus (type 2), whereas in others the oesophagus is of normal calibre and exhibits high-pressure contractile (although non-peristaltic) activity (spastic oesophagus, vigorous achalasia). The two main methods are forceful dilatation of the cardia and laparoscopic cardiomyotomy (conventionally performed together with a partial fundoplication), although in recent years there has been growing interest in the use of peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM).

choices.text: Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins is rare
Protein malnutrition is the most significant long-term complication seen after BPD.
Long-term weight-loss results are not as good as with gastric bypass.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with long-standing morbid obesity is evaluated for bariatric surgery. He is 5 ft 8 inch tall, weighs 210 kg with a BMI of 72.2 kg/m2, and has limited mobility requiring the assistance of a walker. His medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and GERD. Which of the following is true when discussing BPD as an option for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most significant long-term complication following BPD/DS is protein malnutrition, which occurs in up to 12% of the patients. Malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins is another major problem following surgery, with depressed levels of vitamins A, D, and K occurring in 63%–69% of patients. Following BPD/DS, three to four loose bowel movements a day, excessive flatulence, and foul-smelling stool may be normal and are results of the malabsorptive nature of the procedure.

choices.text: Endoscopic evaluation of the injury and stenting
Left thoracotomy, primary repair, myotomy, and drain placement
Laparotomy, primary repair, and gastrostomy tube Placement

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department 8 h after balloon dilation of her esophagus with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain. She was found to be febrile, tachycardic, and normotensive. Esophagography showed “bird’s beak” narrowing and a leak at the distal end of the esophagus with contrast material in the left side of the chest. After fluid resuscitation and antibiotics, which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The rate of esophageal perforation after endoscopic pneumatic dilation is low (4%). Early diagnosis plus treatment of esophageal perforation is associated with improved survival. In stable patients with a contained perforation, there is a role for nonoperable management consisting of nothing by mouth and intravenous antibiotics. If the perforation is because of an underlying pathology that causes distal obstruction (e.g., achalasia, esophageal cancer, or stricture), the operative treatment must address the underlying disease. A myotomy should be performed in patients with achalasia and esophagectomy considered only in those with a sigmoid esophagus or megaesophagus.

choices.text: Endoscopic biopsy should be avoided because of the risk for perforation.
CT is excellent for tumor staging.
Positron emission tomography (PET) is an excellent tool for staging and can be used as a single diagnostic modality.
EUS is more sensitive than CT for evaluating the celiac lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 75-year-old white man with a history of alcohol abuse, 40-pack-per year tobacco use, and long-standing GERD controlled by antacids is evaluated for dysphagia and weight loss. Esophagography shows an apple core lesion at the distal end of the esophagus. Which of the following is true regarding further workup?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Barium esophagography is a good first test for patients with dysphagia and a history suspicious for cancer. Although CT is accurate for M staging, it is only 57% accurate for T staging. PET is an excellent tool that can be used to evaluate N and M staging but should not be used as a single diagnostic modality. MRI is excellent for detecting metastatic and T4 lesions. EUS is the most important diagnostic tool in esophageal cancer staging. Tissue samples can be obtained from lymph nodes, as well as from the primary lesion. EUS is more sensitive and specific than CT in evaluating the celiac lymph nodes

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alician blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
Adenocarcinoma of O-G junction is a complication

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Barrett's esophagus is incorrect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic: Barrett's esophagus is characterized by the presence of specialized columnar cells that include goblet cells, which are responsible for producing mucus. This presence of goblet cells in the columnar epithelium is a hallmark of Barrett's esophagus, distinguishing it from other types of epithelium that might contain mucus-secreting foveolar cells. The key feature of Barrett's esophagus is the transformation of the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus into this specialized columnar type.

questions.text: What type of achalasia does a 32-year-old male with a diagnosis of achalasia cardia have, based on the findings of high-resolution manometry which showed simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal esophagus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Type III achalasia is defined by an elevated median integrated relaxation pressure (IRP) greater than 15 mmHg, absence of normal peristalsis, and premature spastic contractions, with distal contractile integral (DCI) values exceeding 450 mmHg·s·cm in at least 20% of swallows. In this case, the patient shows massive, simultaneous high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, consistent with the criteria for Type III achalasia according to the Chicago Classification.

choices.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: All are true about Barrett oesophagus except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma Barrett's esophagus is primarily associated with an increased risk of adenocarcinoma, particularly of the esophagus, rather than squamous cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma is more commonly associated with other risk factors, such as smoking and alcohol use, rather than Barrett's esophagus itself.

questions.text: Which of the following terms best reflects the morphologic reaction seen in Barrett's esophagus due to prolonged injury?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Glandular metaplasia In Barrett's esophagus, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium, which is a type of glandular metaplasia often due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: Which of the following is a pre-malignant lesion to esophageal carcinoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Barrett's esophagus Barrett's esophagus is a chronic complication of gastroesophageal reflux disease(GERD). It increases the risk of carcinoma. It is a metaplasia caused by chronic acid exposure.
